Despite Loss at Polls,
ASAC Ready for Year
By RICHARD GURLITZ
Despite the fact that a similar
committee was defeated in the
November, 1970 governance
referendum, the Arts and
Sciences Advisory Committee is
preparing to enter its second
year of operation.
The ASAC, as described by
Dean George Benton, founder of
the committee, is a
representative group similar to
the Arts and Sciences
Representative Council detailed
in the governance proposal
formed two summers ago.
Representative Body
The ASAC was to be the
prime representative body at
Hopkins, incorporating faculty,
graduate students, and
undergraduates, according to the
defeated governance proposal. In
February of this year, Dean
Benton formed the ASAC, an
advisory committee consisting of
faculty, graduate students, and
undergraduates.
The undergraduate members
of the ASAC will not be elected
by the student body, but will be
appointed by the dean's office
on recommendation from the
Student Council.
Members Chosen
Shepard Hoffman, a
sophomore member of the
Student Council and interviewer
for the council's selection
process, said that student
response to the notion of an
ASAC was favorable. He has
received over sixty applications
for the three undergraduate
positions open.
"I'm looking for
strong-minded people who won't

be afraid to stand up at a
meeting," commented Hoffman.
He added that the interviews
would last at most fifteen
minutes. The three candidates
for the committee will be
announced tonight.
ASAC Operations
Chris Ohly, an SC member
last year and a member of the
previousTAC,1
said that the
capacity of the ASAC, as it was
originally defined by Benton,
limited it to a totally advisory
status. It was to concern itself
only with issues not covered by
any other committee at
Hopkins.
"Dean Benton has the power
to create any committee he
deems necessary," said Ohly,
commenting on the validity of
the ASAC.
Until the time of the defeat of
the proposed governance
program, a Temporary Advisory
Council had been in operation.
Since the TAC so closely
imitated the proposed and
defeated ASRC, it was
disbanded shortly after the
November referendum.
The ASAC convened for the
first time last March. At that
meeting, Benton noted, "I'd like
to see this be a discussion
committee. The point of the
committee is for me to gain
information from you."
The ASAC meetings of last
year dealt mostly with
proceedural matters. "So far
there have been no tests on the
power of the ASAC," said Ohly.
Ohly added that the advisory
nature of the board rendered it
to a large extent ineffectual, as
with the defeated ASRC.

Small Departments Spared
By SUE WOOLHISER
Encouraged by the financial
progress that has recently been
made in decreasing the
University's deficit, Dean
Benton indicated that small
departments are in no immediate
danger of being discontinued.
Last year, the tight fiscal
situation threatened the
existence of small departments,
and the Russian program was
ended.
Noting that $1.5 million has
been cut from the Arts and
Sciences Administration budget,
Dean Benton said, "We can
probably get back in the black
within three years without
drastic program changes."
Benton remarked, "Whatever
prograr4matic\ changes will be
made will depend on the
effectiveness of a program,
rather than , according to
departments." ,
Gradual Changes
The changes that will be made
will be gradual ones. Programs
that have not been deemed of
viable strength will either be
phased out, integrated into other
departments or offered through
exchange programs with other
colleges and universities.
According to Benton, every
small department has a unique
position within the University.

The writing program, for
example, although a small
department, attracts a large
number of students. Such
departments as Classics,
however, do not have a large
enrolment, but have a traditional
position within a university. The
Department of Near Eastern
Studies' emphasis is at the
graduate rather than the
undergraduate level.
In deciding the future of the
small departments, the
effectiveness of their programs
will be the main evaluating
factor, but student interest in
the program and the position of
the department within the
University will also be
considered.
Creative
"No one knows at this point
what programmatic changes will
be made," said Benton. "There
is no hurry on such decisions.
We have the time to make
changes slowly and not be
stampeded," He said, "By
making these changes gradual, it
is more likely that they will be
creative, solidifying changes
rather than destructive ones."
The position of the small
departments brings out the
larger problems that face the
entire academic program.
Students tend to shift their

George Benton
fields of interest faster than the
University can accomodate,
according to Benton. The
University, Benton contended,
changes with an eye to the ,
future and tries to see through
fads.
Be fore financial difficulty
became evident in the late
sixties, the faculty was increased
— adding to the present tight
situation. New programs were
also started that never were
brought up to their originally
intended strength. Under, such
conditions it is the small
departments that are
re-evaluated first.

By RICHARD BLAND
People have heard perhaps of
Gerry Bates. They may have
seen his picture in the
News-Letter. They probably
know that he's president of the
Student Council. What they may
not know is that he's married,
24 years old and has a four year
old child. There must be fewer
people who have heard that he
spent three and a half years with
the Air Force in New Mexico.
In any case, he did. He was an
aerial motion picture camera
man flying in F-4, F-100 and
F-106 jet fighters. This was after
he'd spent one semester at Joliet
Junior College in Joliet, Illinois,
which is his hometown.
Gerry is glad his service is
done with. But he feels it helped
him in many ways. "I found out
what I wanted to do. It opened
my eyes to what living is all
about, the way the world really
is, how cold it can be."

the confusions and frustrations

much about real life. "High
school can be a pretty sheltered

college, but once you get out
and get responsibility, you really
start living. Undergrads are
talking a lot about the way
things are, and they are right,
there's a lot of room for.
improvement."
Gerry lives in McCoy Hall
with his wife, Linda, and his
four year old son, Jeffrey. He
likes to sit at his dining room
table. "I'm a family man. I don't
have time for dates," he laughs.
He's tall, with slender build,
handsome affable features and is
usually smiling. "I guess I don't
have to worry. Being married
helps me tend not to be quite as
emotional. I take things more
calmly."

furnished with books, colorful
pictures and some Mexican
sculpture.

Thinclads Outrun UMBC
The Johns Hopkins University
cross country team firmly
established its season record at
2-0 last Saturday by running
over UMBC by a score of 21-38.
Once again, it was Hopkins'
fantastic duo of Russ Dubiel and
Jeff Greve which placed first and
second, with times of 27:57 and
28:09 respectively. What is
especially noteworthy, though,
is that both of these times broke
the previous record for the 5.1

mile University of Maryland
course.
But in addition to these two
runners the rest of the Blue Jay
team also looked impressive in
the win as sophomores Austin
Doyle and Craig Slotke and
freshman Dave Piccoli captured
fifth, sixth and seventh place,
while Bill Schickler finished
ninth to round out the scoring.
One of those impressed with
the results of the meet was

co-captain Ed Cummings, who
especially noted the
improvement of several members
of the team and the increasing
evidence of spirit and
competitive desire among the
runners.
As Cummings stated, "There
is so much competition among
team members this year that
there is no opportunity to settle
back and dog it."

Tyner Leads Booters
To Red Devils Victory
By JEFF FORMAN
Scott Tyner's goal with 1:45
left in the game led the Johns
Hopkins University soccer team
to a 1 to 0 victory over the
Dickinson Red Devils on
Saturday.
Tyner's seventh goal of the
season came after Roberto
Aguerro took a direct kick at the
Red Devil goalie, Bill Beaver.
After co-captain Bob Szeles shot
the rebound which again
bounced off Beaver, Tyner then
headed the second rebound into
the net to climax a game which
saw the Blue Jays in command
most of the time.
Hopkins kept control partly
because the defense,

spearheaded by Charlie Gilman,
would not allow the Red Devils
to start a drive. Consequently,
Hopkins took 43 shots on goal
while Dickinson could manage
only 14.
Tense Moment
Keith Naunheim, the Hopkins
goalie, had very little trouble
preserving his shutout, the only
tense moment coming when he
came out of the goal to make a
save. The subsequent bunching
up left Hopkins with an open
net, but Dickinson could not get
the ball through the crowd.
The Blue Jays travel to
Swarthmore this Saturday but
return home next Wednesday to
meet Gettysburg at 3:00 p.m.
